item.title: Golem: Framework for Building Production Grade Shiny Apps - Lance Upton
item.description: Abstract Lance introduced us to the R package named golem, which can be used to create production-grade Shiny applications. If you are into R based web application development and Shiny, this framework may be your guide to keeping your code organized with it’s embedded best practices. Lance graciously agreed to do this meetup session for us at extremely short notice. So there were a few hiccups during the live demo. But he agreed to do another recording after the meetup to showcase Golem again which went more smoothly.

item.title: Plumber Package Discussion - Bill McLellan
item.description: Bill led the discussion of Plumber package (video)

item.title: Renv package - Derrick Kearney
item.description: Abstract Join us for two presentation. 1. Vijay Lulla will be leading us in an exploration of the unexpected parts of the R language in a round of R Trivia! 2. Derrick Kearney will share usage scenarios for renv, an R package that helps create portable and reproducible development environments. The package author, Kevin Ushey, explains the basics in his video. We’ll build on top of it with practical usage examples.

item.title: rstudio::conf(2020) Recap - Derrick Kearney
item.description: Derrick reviewed the highlights from rstudio::conf (2020) Links: link to video link to slides

item.title: RNA Sequencing: Analysis of gene expression data using R - Nadia Atallah Lanman
item.description: Abstract During the last decade, Next Generation sequencing technologies have revolutionized basic, applied, and clinical research. This IndyUseR tutorial is a brief overview, covering the basics of RNA-seq experimental planning and data analysis. The bulk of the analysis will focus on analyses that occur once a gene expression count matrix is obtained. We will cover quality control, differential gene expression analysis, pathway analysis, enrichment analysis, and data visualization. Links: 1. Presentation html file (link)

item.title: Reproducible workflows at scale with Drake - Will Landau
item.description: Abstract Ambitious workflows in R, such as machine learning analyses, can be difficult to manage. A single round of computation can take several hours to complete, and routine updates to the code and data tend to invalidate hard-earned results. You can enhance the maintainability, hygiene, speed, scale, and reproducibility of such projects with the drake R package. drake resolves the dependency structure of your analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and organizes the output so you rarely have to think about data files.

item.title: RCall: Using Julia from R - Vijay Lulla
Learning to Build a Minimal R Package - Shankar
Machine Learning with Caret - Roy B., R Shiny Application - Lance Upton
Explore Simmer Package for Discrete Event Simulation in R
item.description: Abstract Discrete event simulation is a powerful approach to model real life processes that consist of a sequence of discrete events. An example of such system is queue in a coffee shop. We will explore the package simmer and work through some examples from the vignettes to learn how simmer can be used for doing discrete event simulation in R.

item.title: Creating (Web) Maps with R - Stephen Roecker
item.description: Abstract Most data has a spatial dimension to it. Knowing ‘where’ the data is coming from is often as crucial as knowing the ‘what’, ‘when’ and ‘who’ dimensions of a given dataset. Therefore it should be no surprise that R has a rich suite of packages for constructing maps and analyzing spatial data. R’s capability has grown so much over the years that it’s functionality rivals many dedicated geographic information systems (GIS).

item.title: Putting the R in Docker: An introduction to single application containers by Derrick Kearney
item.description: Location of slides.

item.title: Recap of rstudio::conf 2019 - Derrick Kearney and Will Landau
item.description: Derrick and Will gave an overview of rstudio::conf 2019 and learning from it. Material covered during the meetup along with link to slides is in this location.

item.title: Discussion of 2019 Plans
item.description: We discussed plans for 2019. We had sent a survey to the folks in IndyUseR meetup group (~400 members). We got only 13 responses. We reviewed the responses and factored those into our discussions. The summary of the 13 responses are in this location. We discussed the following: Have zoom meetings for the meetups so that folks can join online and location is less of a barrier Try to have meeting topics confirmed well before the meetup date Talked about having intro level talks to make the group welcoming to new R users Talked about bringing back R trivia segment for each of the meetups Will look into a R Training day Topics of Interest: Some of the topics of interest listed in this year’s survey and talked about last year are listed in this location.

item.title: Learnings from EARL Conference - Derrick Kearney and Roy Budhaditya
item.description: Abstract Derrick and Roy shared their learnings from the recent EARL conference that they attended.

item.title: An introduction to the US Federal Budget with R by Stephen
item.description: Abstract The budget of the United States Federal Government is often a contentious issue. This presentation will provide a ‘rough’ introduction, covering where to get the data, provide a breakdown of the numbers, and links to other resources. Link to presentation

item.title: Time Series Group Forecasting with R and Interactive Visualization with ggvis - Roy Budhaditya
item.description: Abstract We will be discussing time series group forecasting in R as well as ggvis visualization. Forecasting is always a topic of importance with the availability of several models such as ARIMA, seasonal decomposition, exponential smoothing and so on. Each and every method produces different or close to similar output based on the data we use. We will be going through a hands on forecast modelling in R using Tidyverse and MAPA package.

item.title: Story Mapping with igraph - Bill McLellan
item.description: Abstract This talk will illustrate how to script a particular R solution for graph analysis to forecast scrum and kanban project cycle time given story links, points and team velocities. This will be followed by brainstorm with the group on how to start generalizing the solution for a project analysis package

item.title: Working with Databases from R - Alex Axthelm
item.description: The abstract of the talk and link to presented material are below. Abstract Alex gave a demo of how to use R code to access and process data form SQL server.

item.title: Neural Networks in R with nnet package - Harry Rowe
item.description: The abstract of the talk and link to presented material are below. Abstract This talk will cover a simple example of neural network using nnet package. The talk would show example of continuous output and classifier (using iris dataset) and show tuning of classifier with repeated cross validation. Link to material from talk

item.title: Turning Your Analysis into an API with Plumber - Derrick Kearney
item.description: Derrick covered the topic of turning Analysis into an API with Plumber. The abstract of the talk and link to presented material are below. Abstract You’ve imported the data, cleaned it up, and built the model. Your next step is to communicate your findings with others. Typically this would mean writing a report or building a web application so other people could visualize how the model works, but sometime your Communicate step is someone else’s Import step.

item.title: Using R in Power BI - Ryan Wade
item.description: Ryan wade covered the topic of using R in Power BI. The abstract of the talk, Ryan’s profile and link to presented material are below. Abstract R is a very powerful statistical programming language that has been gaining a lot of traction in recent years. In early 2015 Microsoft acquired Revolution Analytics, a major provider of software and services for R. Microsoft have since incorporated R in Azure ML, SQL Server 2016, and Power BI.

item.title: Intro to Reticulate Package - Shankar
item.description: Shankar covered the basics of reticulate package. The codes covered in the talk are in this location.

item.title: rstudio::conf2018 and tidyeval Discussion - Will Landau
item.description: Will talked about rstudio::conf2018 and discussed tidyeval concepts that he recently learnt at Hadley Wickham’s rstudio::conf2018 tutorial. (link to Will’s presentation material)

item.title: Discussion of 2018 plans
item.description: We discussed plans for 2018 as a group. Below are notes from the discussion Ideas on content to cover in the meetups trivia short package intro and go through vignette with some extensions go through datasets from different industries people can ask questions (ask a few days before) so that they can be addressed during the meetup Topics of interest: github docker/rocker setting up RStudio/Shiny in cloud (AWS, google cloud etc.

item.title: About
item.description: The IndyUseR Group is dedicated to bringing together users of R (at all levels of experience from beginner to expert level) to exchange knowledge, inspire new users, and spur the adoption of R for innovative research and commercial applications. The meetup page for IndyUseR group is at this location.

2017 Meetings November 2017: Perspective on Base R and Tidyverse by Stephen October 2017: An R Text Mining Case Study - Harry Rowe September 2017: Exploring UN General Debates Kaggle Dataset with R NLP Tools August 2017: Reproducibility and high-performance computing with drake July 2017: R in the development and analysis of forensic credibility assessment tests June 2017: Exploring Simmer - An R Package for Discrete Event Simulation May 2017: Overview of Julia by a R User April 2017: Cybersecurity Discussion March 2017: FREDcast, R Trivia, General Discussion February 2017: FREDcast, R Trivia, Webscraping and htmlWidgets January 2017: Kickoff Meeting for Year, General Discussion, Trends in Statistical Papers Using Google Scholar - Matt Gillam 2016 Meetings November 2016: Predicting NBA Games using SQL R Services - Ryan Wade October 2016: New R tools for workflow management, testing, and reproducibility - Will Landau September 2016: Intro to R Programming at IUPUI - Fred Kukral August 2016: Presentation about feather - Matt Gillam July 2016: UseR 2016 Recap - Adam Simkowski June 2016: Leveraging Weather Data in R - Adam Simkowski May 2016: Big Molecules Meets Big Data: Predicting Protein Tertiary Structure from Combinatorial Chemistry Data - Stan Siranovich April 2016: Using R and Power BI to Analyze US Trade Balance with Other Countries - Ryan Wade March 2016: System Configuration and Development of R in Jupyter Notebook February 2016: Book overview: Mastering Machine Learning with R - Cory Lesmeister January 2016: Webscraping with rvest package - Shankar Vaidyaraman 2015 Meetings November 2015: Typical Excel Tasks in R - Stuart Ward, Demo of a Shiny App that Analyzes Sentiments and Produces Wordcloud of Sentiments - J.
